Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Worker Ownership in US Machine Manufacturing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Approximately 2,500 majority employee owned firms operate in the contemporary US economy and their ownership structure constitutes a drastic alternative to the traditional investor or family-owned firm, yet their productive potential has never been rigorously studied. This project utilizes a three-case comparative ethnography of firms in the U.S. industrial machine manufacturing industry to examine the effects of majority employee ownership and high performance work organization on strategic and operational decision-making. First, how do majority and non-majority employee owned firms govern and implement strategic and operational decision making? Second, how is high productivity work organization governed and implemented in majority employee owned and non-majority employee owned firms? The three selected firms all utilize extensive high productivity work organization practices and operate in the industrial machine manufacturing industry, a particularly challenging context for employee ownership. Two majority employee owned cases serve as critical cases, in that their performance will suggest the possibilities for employee owned firms in less adverse environments. The two employee owned firms vary in the degree of employee direct participation in strategic governance, in order to parse out the effects of employee ownership and employee control. The third firm will be privately owned and will serve as a benchmark. In order to capture the decision-making processes and subjective orientations of workers towards the firm, data will be collected through a combination of in-depth interviews and participant observation, organized around six month internships in each of the firms.

Beyond its intellectual merit, this dissertation will have a range of broader impacts. I am partnering with the University of Wisconsin Center for Cooperatives to develop educational case studies from the two majority employee owned firms. These cases will be made available on the Center's website and will offer guidance for entrepreneurs considering employee ownership as an organizational strategy. Second, part of my agreement with the organizations will be to share my findings and collaborate on research projects to improve their human resource practices and increase the involvement of employees in governance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In order to examine the effects of employee ownership on strategic and operational decision-making in a knowledge-intensive industry, this project involved a two-case comparative ethnography of firms in the U.S. automated manufacturing system integration industry. Manufacturing system integrators design, build, and install the systems of automated manufacturing equipment that populate an increasing proportion of contemporary manufacturing facilities. In these firms, work is organized around collaborative project teams of engineers, machinists, and technicians.

The two firms were selected because they are geographically proximate, similarly sized, and are direct competitors, but have radically different ownership structures. While one firm is a worker cooperative, where each worker has an equal ownership stake, the other firm has a single majority owner. The study focused on three dimensions of strategic and operational decision-making: technology adoption, supply chain relationships, and operational decision-making. In particular, because of the organization of work in this industry, it provided an ideal environment in which to evaluate the impact of ownership structures on work team formation and functioning.

Data was collected through a combination of in-depth interviews and participant observation, organized around 8 month internships in each of the firms. I completed 70 in-depth narrative interviews at the two firms and conducted 384 hours of participant observation. I also secured access to 10 years of financial and payroll data from the two firms, allowing me to construct a dataset with which to compare human resource allocations and various dimensions of performance in the two firms. 

Since completion of data collection, I have presented preliminary results from the study to two public audiences of worker ownership advocates. I am also collaborating with an economist colleague to analyze this data and have produced one conference paper from that collaboration. Papers that use the data have been accepted to three academic conferences to occur in the summer and fall of 2013.
